body_content.explanation: to come close together in a group, for example because it is cold:
examples: Employees huddled round television sets at the company headquarters.
It was so cold that we huddled together for warmth.

body_content.explanation: to sit or stand in a bent position with your arms and legs close to your body, especially because of cold or fear:
examples: Sophie was so frightened by the noise of the fireworks that she huddled (up) in a corner of the room.

body_content.explanation: to discuss something privately in a small group:
examples: After huddling with advisors, the president gave a speech.
We spoke to Democratic lawmakers who are huddling on this issue on Capitol Hill tonight.

body_content.explanation: a small group of people or things that are close together:
examples: A small group of people stood in a huddle at the bus stop.
The campsite comprises a huddle of tents on a bend in the river.

body_content.explanation: to get into a group in order to talk secretly:
examples: The judges went into a huddle to decide the winner.

body_content.explanation: a group formed by the members of a sports team in order to have a discussion, before they separate and continue to play:
examples: I called a huddle and said, "We're going to do something different this time."
